name: Mountain Pose
context: Tadasana is Mountain Pose in Sanskrit. 'Tada' means 'mountain,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a foundational standing pose that emphasizes posture and body alignment.

name: Downward-Facing Dog
context: Adho Mukha Svanasana is Downward-Facing Dog in Sanskrit. 'Adho' means 'down,' 'Mukha' means 'face,' and 'Svanasana' means 'dog pose.' It is a common pose used to stretch and strengthen the entire body.

name: Plank Pose
context: Phalakasana is Plank Pose in Sanskrit. 'Phalaka' means 'plank' or 'board.' It is a core strengthening pose that engages the arms, legs, and abdominal muscles.

name: Four-Limbed Staff Pose
context: Chaturanga Dandasana is Four-Limbed Staff Pose in Sanskrit. 'Chatur' means 'four,' 'Anga' means 'limb,' and 'Danda' means 'staff.' It is a key strength-building pose in yoga, often used as a transition.

name: Upward-Facing Dog
context: Urdhva Mukha Svanasana is Upward-Facing Dog in Sanskrit. 'Urdhva' means 'upward,' 'Mukha' means 'face,' and 'Svanasana' means 'dog pose.' This pose is typically used to open the chest and strengthen the spine.

name: Child's Pose
context: Balasana is Child's Pose in Sanskrit. 'Bala' means 'child,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' This restorative pose is often used for relaxation and to gently stretch the back.

name: Warrior I
context: Virabhadrasana I is Warrior I in Sanskrit. 'Virabhadra' is the name of a mythological warrior and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a powerful pose that strengthens the legs and opens the hips.

name: Warrior II
context: Virabhadrasana II is Warrior II in Sanskrit. It is the second variation of the Warrior pose and emphasizes strength and stability in the lower body.

name: Warrior III
context: Virabhadrasana III is Warrior III in Sanskrit. It is a balancing pose that strengthens the legs and core while improving posture.

name: Extended Side Angle
context: Utthita Parsvakonasana is Extended Side Angle in Sanskrit. 'Utthita' means 'extended,' 'Parsvakona' means 'side angle,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' This pose stretches the legs, hips, and torso while improving balance.

name: Reverse Warrior
context: Viparita Virabhadrasana is Reverse Warrior in Sanskrit. 'Viparita' means 'reverse,' and 'Virabhadrasana' refers to Warrior pose. It stretches the sides of the body and strengthens the legs.

name: Triangle Pose
context: Trikonasana is Triangle Pose in Sanskrit. 'Trikona' means 'triangle,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' This pose helps to lengthen the legs, hips, and torso.

name: Half Moon Pose
context: Ardha Chandrasana is Half Moon Pose in Sanskrit. 'Ardha' means 'half,' 'Chandra' means 'moon,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a balancing pose that stretches the sides of the body.

name: Chair Pose
context: Utkatasana is Chair Pose in Sanskrit. 'Utkata' means 'powerful' or 'fierce,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It strengthens the legs, back, and arms.

name: Goddess Pose
context: Utkata Konasana is Goddess Pose in Sanskrit. 'Utkata' means 'fierce' or 'powerful,' and 'Kona' means 'angle.' It engages the legs and opens the hips.

name: High Lunge
context: Alanasana is High Lunge in Sanskrit. 'Alana' means 'straight' or 'raised,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It helps to stretch the hips and legs.

name: Low Lunge
context: Anjaneyasana is Low Lunge in Sanskrit. 'Anjaneya' is the name of Lord Hanuman, and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a grounding pose that stretches the hips and legs.

name: Pyramid Pose
context: Parsvottanasana is Pyramid Pose in Sanskrit. 'Parsvottana' means 'intense side stretch,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It stretches the hamstrings and hips.

name: Wide-Legged Forward Fold
context: Prasarita Padottanasana is Wide-Legged Forward Fold in Sanskrit. 'Prasarita' means 'wide,' 'Pada' means 'foot,' and 'Uttanasana' means 'forward fold.' It stretches the legs and back.

name: Standing Split
context: Urdhva Prasarita Eka Padasana is Standing Split in Sanskrit. 'Urdhva' means 'upward,' 'Prasarita' means 'wide,' and 'Eka Padasana' means 'one-legged pose.' It stretches the hamstrings and hips.

name: Tree Pose
context: Vrksasana is Tree Pose in Sanskrit. 'Vrksa' means 'tree,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a balancing pose that strengthens the legs and improves stability.

name: Dancer's Pose
context: Natarajasana is Dancer's Pose in Sanskrit. 'Nataraja' refers to the Hindu god of dance, and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a graceful balancing pose that opens the chest and stretches the legs.

name: Eagle Pose
context: Garudasana is Eagle Pose in Sanskrit. 'Garuda' is the mythological king of birds, and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a balancing pose that improves focus and stretches the shoulders and legs.

name: Crow Pose
context: Bakasana is Crow Pose in Sanskrit. 'Baka' means 'crow,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is an arm-balancing pose that strengthens the arms, wrists, and core.

name: Side Crow
context: Parsva Bakasana is Side Crow in Sanskrit. 'Parsva' means 'side,' and 'Bakasana' means 'crow pose.' It is a variation of Crow Pose that involves balancing on one arm while twisting the body.

name: Garland Pose
context: Malasana is Garland Pose in Sanskrit. 'Mala' means 'garland,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' This deep squat is designed to open the hips and stretch the lower back, promoting flexibility and stability. It is often used to prepare the body for seated meditation or to counteract the effects of prolonged sitting.

name: Forearm Stand
context: Pincha Mayurasana is Forearm Stand in Sanskrit. 'Pincha' means 'feather' and 'Mayura' means 'peacock,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' This pose strengthens the shoulders and core while improving balance.

name: Handstand
context: Adho Mukha Vrksasana is Handstand in Sanskrit. 'Adho Mukha' means 'downward-facing,' and 'Vrksasana' means 'tree pose.' It is an advanced inversion pose that builds arm strength and balance.

name: Shoulder Stand
context: Sarvangasana is Shoulder Stand in Sanskrit. 'Sarva' means 'whole' or 'all,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is an inversion pose that strengthens the upper body and promotes circulation.

name: Fish Pose
context: Matsyasana is Fish Pose in Sanskrit. 'Matsya' means 'fish,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a backbend that stretches the chest, neck, and spine.

name: Camel Pose
context: Ustrasana is Camel Pose in Sanskrit. 'Ustra' means 'camel,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a backbend that opens the chest and stretches the front of the body.

name: Bridge Pose
context: Setu Bandhasana is Bridge Pose in Sanskrit. 'Setu' means 'bridge,' and 'Bandha' means 'lock,' with 'Asana' meaning 'pose.' It is a backbend that strengthens the glutes, legs, and back.

name: Wheel Pose
context: Urdhva Dhanurasana is Wheel Pose in Sanskrit. 'Urdhva' means 'upward,' and 'Dhanura' means 'bow,' with 'Asana' meaning 'pose.' It is an intense backbend that opens the chest and stretches the spine.

name: Reclining Bound Angle
context: Supta Baddha Konasana is Reclining Bound Angle in Sanskrit. 'Supta' means 'reclining,' 'Baddha' means 'bound,' and 'Kona' means 'angle.' It is a restorative pose that opens the hips and chest.

name: Legs Up the Wall
context: Viparita Karani is Legs Up the Wall in Sanskrit. 'Viparita' means 'reverse,' and 'Karani' means 'action.' This is a restorative pose that relaxes the legs and promotes circulation.

name: Boat Pose
context: Navasana is Boat Pose in Sanskrit. 'Nava' means 'boat,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a core-strengthening pose that engages the abdominal muscles.

name: Seated Forward Fold
context: Paschimottanasana is Seated Forward Fold in Sanskrit. 'Paschima' means 'west' or 'back,' and 'Uttanasana' means 'intense stretch.' It is a forward bend that stretches the back and hamstrings.

name: Bound Angle
context: Baddha Konasana is Bound Angle in Sanskrit. 'Baddha' means 'bound,' and 'Kona' means 'angle.' It is a seated pose that stretches the hips and groin.

name: Happy Baby Pose
context: Ananda Balasana is Happy Baby Pose in Sanskrit. 'Ananda' means 'bliss,' and 'Bala' means 'child.' This pose gently stretches the hips and lower back.

name: Corpse Pose
context: Savasana is Corpse Pose in Sanskrit. 'Sava' means 'corpse,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a resting pose used for relaxation and integration of practice.

name: Cobra Pose
context: Bhujangasana is Cobra Pose in Sanskrit. 'Bhujanga' means 'snake' or 'serpent,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a backbend that strengthens the spine and opens the chest.

name: Locust Pose
context: Salabhasana is Locust Pose in Sanskrit. 'Salabha' means 'locust,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It strengthens the lower back, legs, and core while promoting better posture.

name: Bow Pose
context: Dhanurasana is Bow Pose in Sanskrit. 'Dhanura' means 'bow,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a backbend that stretches the front body and strengthens the back.

name: Puppy Pose
context: Uttana Shishosana is Puppy Pose in Sanskrit. 'Uttana' means 'extended,' and 'Shishosana' means 'puppy pose.' It is a gentle stretch for the back and shoulders.

name: Cat-Cow Pose
context: Marjaryasana-Bitilasana is Cat-Cow Pose in Sanskrit. 'Marjaryasana' means 'cat pose,' and 'Bitilasana' means 'cow pose.' This dynamic flow warms up the spine and helps increase flexibility.

name: Thread the Needle
context: Parsva Balasana is Thread the Needle in Sanskrit. 'Parsva' means 'side,' and 'Balasana' means 'child's pose.' It is a gentle stretch for the shoulders and upper back.

name: Reverse Plank Pose
context: Purvottanasana is Reverse Plank Pose in Sanskrit. 'Purva' means 'east' or 'front of the body,' and 'Uttana' means 'intense stretch.' This pose stretches the front body, strengthens the arms and core, and promotes openness and confidence through its uplifting posture.

name: Pigeon Pose
context: Eka Pada Rajakapotasana is Pigeon Pose in Sanskrit. 'Eka' means 'one,' 'Pada' means 'foot,' and 'Rajakapotasana' means 'king pigeon pose.' It is a deep hip opener that stretches the hips and thighs.

name: Plow Pose
context: Halasana is Plow Pose in Sanskrit. 'Hala' means 'plow,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' This pose imitates the shape of a plow and is known for its deep stretch along the spine, shoulders, and hamstrings. It calms the mind, relieves tension, and promotes flexibility in the entire back body.

name: Supine Twist
context: Supta Matsyendrasana is Supine Twist in Sanskrit. 'Supta' means 'reclining,' and 'Matsyendra' is the name of a great sage. This pose helps stretch the spine and relieve tension.

name: Half Lord of the Fishes
context: Ardha Matsyendrasana is Half Lord of the Fishes Pose in Sanskrit. 'Ardha' means 'half,' 'Matsya' means 'fish,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a seated twist that helps with spinal mobility.

name: Side Plank
context: Vasisthasana is Side Plank in Sanskrit. 'Vasistha' is the name of a sage, and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a balance pose that strengthens the arms, shoulders, and core.

name: Wild Thing
context: Camatkarasana is Wild Thing Pose in Sanskrit. 'Camatkara' means 'wonder' or 'surprise,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is an energizing backbend and heart opener.

name: Tiger Pose
context: Vyaghrasana is Tiger Pose in Sanskrit. 'Vyaghra' means 'tiger,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a backbend and core strengthening pose.

name: Gate Pose
context: Parighasana is Gate Pose in Sanskrit. 'Parigha' means 'gate,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It stretches the sides of the body and improves flexibility in the legs.

name: Frog Pose
context: Mandukasana is Frog Pose in Sanskrit. 'Manduka' means 'frog,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a deep hip opener and stretch for the groin and thighs.

name: Lizard Pose
context: Utthan Pristhasana is Lizard Pose in Sanskrit. 'Utthan' means 'stretch,' and 'Pristha' means 'back.' It stretches the hips, hamstrings, and groin.

name: Fallen Triangle
context: Patita Tarasana is Fallen Triangle Pose in Sanskrit. 'Patita' means 'fallen,' and 'Tara' means 'star.' It is a variation of Triangle Pose with a focus on the side body and core.

name: Bird of Paradise
context: Svarga Dvijasana is Bird of Paradise in Sanskrit. 'Svarga' means 'heaven,' and 'Dvija' means 'bird.' It is a challenging balance pose with a deep stretch.

name: Extended Hand-to-Big-Toe Pose
context: Utthita Hasta Padangusthasana is Extended Hand-to-Big-Toe Pose in Sanskrit. 'Utthita' means 'extended,' 'Hasta' means 'hand,' and 'Padangustha' means 'big toe.' It is a balancing pose that stretches the legs and improves focus.

name: Standing Forward Fold
context: Uttanasana is Standing Forward Fold in Sanskrit. 'Uttana' means 'intense stretch,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It stretches the hamstrings, spine, and calves.

name: Halfway Lift
context: Ardha Uttanasana is Halfway Lift in Sanskrit. 'Ardha' means 'half,' and 'Uttanasana' means 'intense stretch.' It is a pose that lengthens the spine and strengthens the back.

name: Ragdoll Pose
context: Uttanasana Variation (Ragdoll Pose) is a variation of Standing Forward Fold where the arms are relaxed and the head hangs heavy. It releases tension in the back and neck.

name: Eight-Angle Pose
context: Astavakrasana is Eight-Angle Pose in Sanskrit. 'Asta' means 'eight,' and 'Akra' means 'angle.' It is an advanced arm balance that requires strength and flexibility.

name: Bound Side Angle
context: Baddha Parsvakonasana is Bound Side Angle in Sanskrit. 'Baddha' means 'bound,' and 'Parsvakonasana' means 'side angle pose.' It deepens the stretch of the side angle pose by binding the hands.

name: Bound Forward Fold
context: Baddha Uttanasana is Bound Forward Fold in Sanskrit. 'Baddha' means 'bound,' and 'Uttanasana' means 'intense stretch.' It is a forward fold with the hands bound behind the back.

name: Half Splits
context: Ardha Hanumanasana is Half Splits in Sanskrit. 'Ardha' means 'half,' and 'Hanumanasana' means 'monkey pose.' It is a hamstring stretch where one leg is extended forward and the other is bent.

name: Full Splits
context: Hanumanasana is Full Splits in Sanskrit. 'Hanumana' refers to the monkey god, and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a deep hamstring and hip opener.

name: King Pigeon Pose
context: Eka Pada Rajakapotasana II is King Pigeon Pose in Sanskrit. 'Eka' means 'one,' 'Pada' means 'foot,' and 'Rajakapotasana' means 'king pigeon pose.' It is a deep backbend and hip opener.

name: Lotus Pose
context: Padmasana is Lotus Pose in Sanskrit. 'Padma' means 'lotus,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a seated meditation pose with the legs crossed and feet resting on the opposite thighs.

name: Lotus Forward Fold
context: Pascimottanasana in Padmasana is Lotus Forward Fold. This variation of Forward Fold is done with the legs in Lotus Pose, offering a deep stretch for the back and hamstrings.

name: Cow Face Pose
context: Gomukhasana is Cow Face Pose in Sanskrit. 'Go' means 'cow,' and 'Mukha' means 'face.' It is a seated pose that stretches the shoulders, hips, and thighs.

name: Seated Spinal Twist
context: Ardha Matsyendrasana is Seated Spinal Twist in Sanskrit. 'Ardha' means 'half,' 'Matsya' means 'fish,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a twisting pose that promotes spinal flexibility.

name: Hero Pose
context: Virasana is Hero Pose in Sanskrit. 'Vira' means 'hero,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a seated pose that stretches the legs and strengthens the knees.

name: Revolved Triangle
context: Parivrtta Trikonasana is Revolved Triangle Pose in Sanskrit. 'Parivrtta' means 'revolved,' and 'Trikonasana' means 'triangle pose.' It is a twist that stretches the legs and torso.

context: Parivrtta Parsvakonasana is Revolved Side Angle Pose in Sanskrit. 'Parivrtta' means 'revolved,' and 'Parsvakonasana' means 'side angle pose.' It is a twisting pose that stretches the sides and torso.

context: Bhujapidasana is Shoulder Pressing Pose in Sanskrit. 'Bhujapida' means 'shoulder pressure,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is an arm balance pose that strengthens the shoulders and arms.

context: Ganda Bherundasana is Chin Stand in Sanskrit. 'Ganda' means 'chin,' and 'Bherunda' refers to the mythical bird. It is an advanced arm balance that requires core strength and balance.

context: Vrschikasana is Scorpion Pose in Sanskrit. 'Vrschika' means 'scorpion,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a challenging pose that combines a backbend and balance, requiring flexibility and strength.

name: Half Moon Bound Pose
context: Baddha Ardha Chandrasana is Half Moon Bound Pose in Sanskrit. 'Baddha' means 'bound,' 'Ardha' means 'half,' and 'Chandrasana' means 'moon pose.' It is a standing balance that stretches the side body and opens the hips.

name: Hummingbird Pose
context: Mayurasana is Hummingbird Pose in Sanskrit. 'Mayura' means 'peacock,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a balancing pose where the body hovers above the floor, supported by the arms.

name: Peacock Pose
context: Mayurasana is Peacock Pose in Sanskrit. This is the same as Hummingbird Pose and involves balancing the body on the arms while keeping the legs extended behind.

name: Compass Pose
context: Parivrtta Surya Yantrasana is Compass Pose in Sanskrit. 'Parivrtta' means 'revolved,' 'Surya' means 'sun,' and 'Yantrasana' means 'instrument pose.' It is a deep stretch for the hamstrings and shoulders, requiring flexibility and balance.

name: Sleeping Vishnu
context: Anantasana is Sleeping Vishnu Pose in Sanskrit. 'Ananta' means 'endless,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a deep side stretch that involves balancing on one side with the top leg extended and foot flexed.

name: Dragonfly Pose
context: Maksikanagasana is Dragonfly Pose in Sanskrit. 'Maksika' means 'dragonfly,' and 'Nagasana' means 'serpent pose.' It is an arm balance pose that requires core strength and balance.

name: Grasshopper Pose
context: Maksikanagasana Variation is Grasshopper Pose in Sanskrit. This pose is an arm balance where the legs are extended sideways and the body is balanced on the arms.

name: Baby Grasshopper
context: Parsva Bhuja Dandasana is Baby Grasshopper Pose in Sanskrit. 'Parsva' means 'side,' 'Bhuja' means 'arm,' and 'Dandasana' means 'staff pose.' It is a challenging arm balance with one leg extended to the side.

name: Caterpillar Pose
context: Paschimottanasana Variation is Caterpillar Pose in Sanskrit. It is a seated forward fold variation where the body folds forward with the legs extended, promoting a deep stretch for the spine.

name: Revolved Chair Pose
context: Parivrtta Utkatasana is Revolved Chair Pose in Sanskrit. 'Parivrtta' means 'revolved,' and 'Utkatasana' means 'chair pose.' This pose involves twisting the torso while holding the chair pose.

name: Side Stretch Pose
context: Parsvottanasana is Side Stretch Pose in Sanskrit. 'Parsva' means 'side,' and 'Utthana' means 'intense stretch.' It is a standing pose that stretches the side body and hamstrings.

name: Hero Pose with Recline
context: Supta Virasana is Hero Pose with Recline in Sanskrit. 'Supta' means 'reclined,' and 'Virasana' means 'hero pose.' It is a seated pose with the knees bent and the body reclining back.

name: Intense Side Stretch
context: Parsvottanasana is Intense Side Stretch Pose in Sanskrit. It is a variation of Side Stretch Pose that emphasizes the stretch along the sides of the body and the hamstrings.

name: Revolved Crescent Lunge
context: Parivrtta Alanasana is Revolved Crescent Lunge in Sanskrit. 'Parivrtta' means 'revolved,' and 'Alanasana' refers to 'crescent lunge.' This is a twisting lunge that targets the hips and legs.

name: Tortoise Pose
context: Kurmasana is Tortoise Pose in Sanskrit. 'Kurma' means 'tortoise,' and 'Asana' means 'pose.' It is a seated forward fold pose that stretches the back and legs.

name: One-Legged Bridge Pose
sanskrit_name: Setu Bandha Sarvangasana with one leg lifted
context: Setu Bandha Sarvangasana with one leg lifted is One-Legged Bridge Pose in Sanskrit. 'Setu' means 'bridge,' 'Bandha' means 'lock,' and 'Sarvangasana' means 'shoulder stand.' It is a variation of Bridge Pose with one leg lifted.

name: Wheel Pose Variation
sanskrit_name: Urdhva Dhanurasana with one leg lifted
context: Urdhva Dhanurasana with one leg lifted is Wheel Pose Variation in Sanskrit. 'Urdhva' means 'upward,' 'Dhanurasana' means 'bow pose.' This variation involves lifting one leg during the backbend.

name: Standing Bow Pose
context: Dandayamana Dhanurasana is Standing Bow Pose in Sanskrit. 'Dandayamana' means 'standing with control,' and 'Dhanurasana' means 'bow pose.' It is a balance pose that combines strength and flexibility.
